Estimated that at least {{c1::60-70}}% of cells in our bodies are non-human 

3 reasons for symbiotic relationship
{{c1::
• Microbes in gut are a source of energy (butyrate) & vitamins (biotin, folate, vitamin K)

• Inhibit colonisation by pathogenic spp. (competitive exclusion)
Competition for nutrients & receptors
Producing bacteriocins & fermentation acids

• We provide niches and nutrients for microbial survival / proliferation
}}

• Vaginal tract:
•Healthy individuals – predominance of {{c1::Lactobacilli, eg. Lactobacillus crispatus}}
•Bacterial vaginosis – diverse range of organisms eg. coliforms, yeasts, etc with paucity of lactobacilli

• {{c1::Staphylococcus epidermidis}} on skin -> IV line-related bloodstream infection

• {{c1::Escherichia coli}} in your gut -> peritonitis following perforated appendix

• {{c1::Viridans streptococci}} in oral cavity (normal flora) -> common pathogens in subacute bacterial endocarditis

•One-third of the general population may have {{c1::Staphylococcus aureus}} in their noses

What makes bacteria gram negative vs positive
Thinner peptidoglycan layer means colour can be removed more easily

C. tetani -> tetanus

Life expectancy : {{c1::average}} number of years of individual of {{c1::given age}} is expected to live to,if current {{c1::mortality}} rates continue

Morbidity= freq. of disease
Mortality= Freq. of death
Prevalence= Proportion of pop. that has condition at point in time
Incidence= Number of new cases of a disease/illness that develop in population at risk during a specified time period
Define risk, what is the difference between relative risk and attributable risk

Risk: probabilty that an individual will develop an outcome in a specified time period

Relative risk: ratio Ie/Iu
Attributable risk: difference Ie - Iu

I- incidence
e-exposed
u-unexposed

A)Receptor activation: monomers > dimerization > autophosphorylation
B)Induce expression of transcription factor genes 
C)Signal transduction and second messengers

Which is not a cell adhesion molecule?
Adhesive glycoproteins/Cell adhesion Molecules: Laminin, fibronectin, thrombospondin, integrins (bind ECM components to each other, and to other cells)
Proteoglycans are found in {{c1::cartilage in joints}}
Proteoglycans: sugars linked to proteins; form highly hydrated compressible gels
Elastin fibres consist of central core of {{c1::elastin}} protein surrounded by meshlike {{c1::fibrillin (glycoprotein)}}
Elastin: Elastic fibres allows tissue to recoil and return to normal after physical stress.

Integrins
bind {{c1::fibronectin}} and {{c1::laminin}} connecting cells to the {{c1::ECM}} and other cells
Fibronectin {{c1::stabilises}} the blood clot that fills the space created by a wound.
FAK is activated by {{c1::integrin}} binding to {{c1::fibronectin}} and it is {{c1::tyrosine phosphorylated}} (how it is activated)
Which is the approiate time scale for this: Deposition of loose ECM-“Granulation tissue”: pink, soft, granular gross appearance

< 24 hr Formation of new blood vessels   (angiogenesis), fibroblast migration and   proliferation (lay down collagen)

5 days+ Maturation and organization (remodeling) of fibrous tissue

What does full blood count (FBC) measure? (6)

-RBC count
-WBC count

{{c1::Hematopoiesis}} is a term describing the formation and development of blood cells.

Hematopoiesis begins as early as the {{c1::19th}} day after fertilization in the {{c1::yolk sac of the embryo}}
-Only {{c1::erythrocytes}} are made
-The RBCs contain unique fetal{{c1::hemoglobins}}
-At about 6 weeks of gestation, yolk sac production of erythrocytes decreases and production of RBCs in the human embryo itself begins.

-The fetal {{c1::liver}} becomes the chief site of blood cell production
-The {{c1::spleen, kidney, thymus, and lymph nodes}} (4) serve as minor sites of blood cell production
-the bone marrow becomes the primary site of hematopoiesis at about {{c1::6 months of gestation}} and continues throughout life.
-When the bone marrow becomes the chief site of hematopoiesis, leukocyte and thrombocyte production become more prominent.

-Hematopoiesis in the bone marrow is called {{c1::medullary haematopoiesis}}
-Hematopoiesis in areas other then the bone marrow is called {{c1::extramedullary hematopoiesis}}

-Extramedullary hematopoiesis may occur in fetal hematopoietic tissue (liver and spleen) of an adult when the bone marrow cannot meet the physiologic needs of the tissues.  This can lead to hepatomegaly and/or splenomegaly (increase in size of the liver and/or spleen because of increased functions in the organs).
The mononuclear phagocytic system also called reticular endothelial system, RES) is involved in {{c1::cellular destruction}} and it includes (3)

-Circulating blood monocytes
-Fixed macrophages in the bone marrow, liver, spleen, and lymph nodes
-Free macrophages
¢These cells are involved in:
Engulfing particulate matter
Processing of antigens for lymphocyte presentation
Removal of damaged or senescent (aged) cells

{{c1::Spleen}} – contains the largest collection of lymphocytes and mononuclear phagocytes in the body.
Name its 3 functions

The spleen functions in:
¢Filtering and destruction of senescent (aged) or damaged RBCS – also called culling
¢Removal of particles (are found in some types of anemia) from RBC membranes – also called pitting – this causes a decrease in the surface to volume ratio of the RBC resulting in the formation of spherocytes (more on this later)
¢Enforcing close contact of blood borne antigens with lymphocytes and phagocytic cells – this is more important in children particularly in protection of the host from infections due to enveloped organisms

-Sequestering {{c1::1/3}} of the platlet mass – in massive splenomegaly this can lead to peripheral {{c1::thrombocytopenia (decrease in platlets in the peripheral blood)}}

-After a {{c1::splenectomy (removal of the spleen)}}, RBC inclusions and abnormal RBC shapes are seen.  Culling is taken over by the {{c1::liver}} which is less effective in performing all of the {{c1::splenic}} functions

{{c1::Hypersplenism (splenomegaly)}} – in a number of conditions the spleen may become enlarged and through an exaggeration of its normal functions of filtering, and destruction and sequestering, it may cause {{c1::anemia (may be caused by decreased RBCs)}}, {{c1::leukopenia (decreased WBCs)}}, or {{c1::thrombocytopenia}} or combinations of these cytopenias.  When all three cell types are decreased this is called pancytopenia.

There are two types of hypersplenism:

-Primary – no underlying disease has been identified
-Secondary – caused by an underlying disorder such as:
Inflammatory diseases
Infectious diseases
Blood disorders that cause compensatory or workload hypertrophy of the organ such as:
  Abnormal blood cells, antibody coated blood cells, hereditary spherocytosis, idiopathic throbocytopenic purpura (ITP)
The effects of these are relieved by splenectomy

-Lymph is formed from {{c1::blood fluid that escapes into the connective tissue.}}

-Lymph nodes are composed of {{c1::lymphocytes, macrophages, and a reticular network.}} (3)

They act as filters to remove foreign particles by phagocytic cells

-As antigens pass through the lymph nodes, they come into contact with and stimulate immunocompetent lymphocytes to proliferate and differentiate into {{c1::effector}} cells.

The structure of the lymph node consists of :
-An inner area called the {{c1::medulla}} which contains {{c1::
plasma cells
}}

-An outer area called the cortex which contains follicles with T lymphocytes and macrophages surrounded by B lymphocytes, True/false?

False
An outer area called the cortex which contains follicles with B lymphocytes surrounded by T lymphocytes and macrophages

-The  thymus serves as a compartment for the maturation of {{c1::T lymphocytes}} into immunocompetent T cells.  The hormone {{c1::thymosin}} plays a role in this process.

The structure of the thymus consists of:
¢An outer area called the cortex which is densely packed with small lymphocytes and macrophages, T/F?
¢An inner area called the medulla which is less cellular with a few lymphocytes, macrophages, and epithelial cells, T/F?

Bone marrow – is located inside {{c1::spongy}} bone
In a normal adult, ½ of the bone marrow is hematopoietically active ({{c1::red}} marrow) and ½ is inactive, fatty marrow ({{c1::yellow}} marrow).
-The marrow contains Erythroid (RBC), leukocyte (WBC) precursors and platlet precursors, T/F?
-Early in life most of the marrow is red marrow and it gradually decreases with age to the adult level of {{c2::50}}%.

True

-In certain pathologic states the bone marrow can increase its activity to 5-10X its normal rate.
¢ When this happens, the bone marrow is said to be hyperplastic because it replaces the yellow marrow with red marrow.

Mature blood cells have a limited life span and with the exception of {{c1::lymphocytes}}, are incapable of self-renewal.

-Replacement of peripheral hematopoietic cells is a function of the {{c1::pluripotential (totipotential)}} stem cells found in the {{c1::bone marrow}}

-Hematopoietic cells can be divided into three cellular compartments based on maturity:
-{{c1::Pluripotential}} stem cell capable of self-renewal and differentiation into all blood cell lines.
-{{c1::Committed proginator}} stem cells destined to develop into distinct cell lines
-{{c1::Mature cells}} with specialized functions

Fatty Acids
•May be {{c1::esterified with glycerol}} to form triglycerides, or be non-esterified or free (NEFA or FFA)
•FFA liberated from {{c1::adipose}} tissue are transported mainly bound to {{c1::albumin}}, to the liver and muscle where they are metabolised providing a significant portion of the energy requirements of the body

{{c1::Saturated fatty acid}}: Fatty acids which contain the maximum possible number of hydrogen atoms, 
Give an example

Fats containing {{c1::Saturated fatty acid}} tend to be {{c1::solid}} at room temperature.
each carbon in the chain has two hydrogen atoms attached to it are "saturated" with hydrogen atoms.

Mono-unsaturated fatty acid: Contain a single carbon-to-carbon "double" bond. Tend to be {{c1::liquid}} at room temperature 

Give an example, 2 cooking examples

corn oil, sunflower oil

The double bond puts a "kink" in the chain which takes up more room than a straight chained fatty acids.

{{c1::Poly-unsaturated fatty acid}}:  Have >1 double bond.
Omega-3 (ω3) and omega-6 (ω6) fatty acids are examples
Give a plant based example

Linoleic acid is a key precursor to some prostaglandins, thromboxanes and leucotrienes.
Sunflower, safflower, corn oil & avocado are particularly rich in it.

Essential Fatty Acids
{{c1::Alpha-linolenic acid, omega 3}} is also a precursor to prostaglandins, thromboxanes and leucotrienes.

Fish oil is rich in the an essential fatty acid {{c1::omega−3}} derivatives {{c1::EPA}} and {{c1::DHA}}
Green leaves and linseed oil are rich in it.

{{c1::Trans-unsaturated fatty acids}}: Largely are product of hydrogenation of fats to produce foodstuff with a longer shelf-life.
The evidence suggests they may be harmful in relation to the risk of cardiovascular disease.

Triglycerides:three fatty acid molecules {{c1::esterified}} to a {{c1::glycerol}} molecule.
•They are transported from the {{c1::intestine}} and the liver in {{c1::lipoprotein}} particles
•{{c1::Plasma}} triglyceride levels rise after a fatty meal and remain increased for several hours

{{c1::Cholesterol}}: precursor
to many physiologically important compounds (bile acids, steroid hormones)

•About 2/3’s of the plasma cholesterol is esterified with fatty acids to form cholesterol esters
•Important component of lipoproteins

Phospholipids: Complex lipids, resembling triglycerides, but containing {{c1::phosphate}} and a {{c1::nitrogenous base}}  in place of one fatty acid
Which part is hydrophilic?

•Important components of cell membranes and lipoproteins, maintaining the solubility of triglycerides and cholesterol

The nitrogen part is hydrophilic

Lipoproteins
•Plasma lipids are derived from food or are synthesized in the body
•As lipids are fairly insoluble in water they are carried in body fluids as soluble protein complexes known as lipoproteins
•They have a core of insoluble {{c1::cholesterol esters}} and {{c1::triglycerides}} surrounded by proteins, phospholipids and free cholesterol with their {{c1::water}} soluble groups facing outwards.

Classified by their {{c1::density}} which correlates directly with their {{c1::protein}} concentration and inversely with their {{c1::size}}

What do Chylomicrons do?
What do VLDLs do?

•Chylomicrons transport exogenous lipid from the intestine to all cells

•VLDL (very low density lipoprotein) transports endogenous lipid from the liver to cells

{{c1::HDL }}: involved in the transport of cholesterol from the cells to the liver, the main protein is apoA

{{c1::LDL}} formed from VLDL, transports cholesterol to cells, the main protein is apoB

{{c1::Atherosclerosis}}: Disease of arteries, resulting in the formation of multiple plaques (AKA {{c1::atheromas}}) within the arteries

Plaques
•pathological accumulation of cells or cell debris, which contain lipids (cholesterol & fatty acids), {{c1::calcium}} & fibrous connective tissue within the walls of arteries
•The debris accumulates between the endothelium and the {{c1::smooth muscle wall (media)}}

{{c1::Atheromas}} reduce blood flow leading to:
•{{c1::Coronary}} Artery Disease
•{{c1::Cerebrovascular}} Disease
{{c1::Peripheral}} Vascular Disease

Schema of Atherogenesis
•Minor endothelial damage, Name 4 causes {{c1::(turbulence, relative anoxia, hypertension, oxidation or glycation)}}
•{{c1::LDL}} particles cross the damaged endothelium
•Circulating monocytes attracted by the damaged endothelium & enter the {{c1::subendothelial}} space.
•LDL particles in the artery wall are {{c1::oxidised}} by oxygen free radicals name 4 sources {{c1::(present in cigarette smoke, formed during glycation reactions, generated by macrophages deliberately to kill bacteria or leaking from various oxidative pathways)}}
•Oxidised LDL is taken up rapidly by macrophages (AKA {{c1::foam cells}})
Schema of Atherogenesis

Schema of Atherogenesis
•Collagen elaborated by {{c1::fibroblasts}} comes to overlie the foam cells, which undergo necrosis or apoptosis
•This results in the formation of a pool of extracellular {{c1::cholesterol}} trapped beneath a {{c1::fibrous}} cap.
•At the shoulder of the {{c1::atheromatous}} lesion active foam cell formation continues & the lesion advances across the inner surface of the artery.
•Plaques can either obstruct blood flow resulting in ischaemia to the peripheral tissue or rupture with thrombus formation at the site of {{c1::the cap}} leading to {{c1::peripheral}} infarction.

Secondary Hyperlipidemias
{{c1::Endocrine}}
•Diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, pituitary disease

{{c1::Renal}} disease

Drugs

•Myeloma, macroglobulinemia, SLE

Hyperuricemia

Nutritional
•Obesity, alcohol, anorexia nervosa

Familial Hypercholesterolemia (FH)
{{c1::Single}} gene defect 
Type A: affects {{c1::LDL}} receptor
Type B: Loss-of-function mutation of the {{c1::apolipoprotein B}} gene
Type C: Gain-of-function {{c1::PCSK9}} mutations 

Prevalence
•Most important syndrome leading to premature {{c1::CHD}}
•Commonest genetic disease in Europe, 1 in {{c1::300}}

Natural History
•CHD occur between 25-50 in 50% of untreated males
•50% of untreated men will have died from IHD by 60
•women generally have an onset about {{c1::10}} years after men

{{c1::PCSK9}}: Marks LDL receptor for degradation 
Laboratory Diagnosis
•Average untreated cholesterol ~ {{c1::9}} mmol/L
•Usually range from {{c1::7.5-14}} mmol/L

What is Xanthomata and where does it usually occur?
What is Xanthelasma and where does it occur?

Xanthomata is a deposition of yellowish cholesterol-rich material
•commonly in tendons, usually only in adults
•most commonly in knuckles of Achilles tendons

Xanthelasma are cholesterol-filled plaques that usually appear on the eyelids.

{{c1::Shock}} :circulatory failure that results in inadequate cellular oxygen utilisation by tissues, can only be sustained for short time before {{c1::death}} ensues

3 criteria for diagnosis

Shock affects 1/3 of ICU patients, Outcome depends on cause, age, co-morbidities, management

-Hypotension (e.g. mean P < 70 mmHg)
-Hypo-perfusion (e.g. of skin, renal and neurological signs)
-Elevated lactate (sign of abnormal utilisation of oxygen)

Effects of Shock
-Widespread ischaemia, T/F {{c1::true}}

-If massive insult, death ensues before hypoxic changes are evident, T/F {{c1::True}}


-Brain, heart and the lungs are most susceptible T/F {{c1::True}}

- Kidney and adrenals are least susceptible, T/F {{c1::False}} 

-Once decompensation occurs, complex metabolic derangements including respiratory acidosis and epithealium dysfunction contribute to a lethal downward spiral and fatality, T/F {{c1::False}}

Hypoxia causes reversible cell injury that progresses to irreversible injury and cell death

-Brain, kidney, heart, lungs, adrenals are most susceptible

-Once decompensation occurs, complex metabolic derangements including metabolic acidosis and endothelial dysfunction contribute to a lethal downward spiral and fatality,

Sepsis
Name 3 sources of infection

•{{c1::GPB and GNB}} account for majority
•25% {{c1::polymicrobial}}
•25% {{c1::MDR multidrug resistant}} organisms
•2-4%  {{c1::viral and parasitic }}
•Blood cultures negative in {{c1::1/3rd}} of cases

Sources of infection
•Pneumonia
•Blood stream including infective endocarditis
•Intravascular catheter related
•Intra-abdominal
•Urological
•Surgical wounds
•Others: post-delivery, necrotising fasciitis, menstrual toxic shock syndrome

Severe sepsis
Cytokines are released by the bacteria, T/F {{c1::False}}

effect of this cytokine storm is
1. Dilatation  -  under perfusion of organs and increased permability, T/F {{c1::True}}
2. Systemic effects -  lactic {{c1::acidosis}}, {{c1::metabolic}} acidosis; {{c1::reduced}} heart  contractility;  
3. Eventual shift from pro inflammatory to immune suppression, Why?

Glucose is increased due to resistance to insulin, T/F {{c1::True}}

What causes increased thrombosis?

Why?Glucose inhibitory of effect of polys and lymphocytes are apoptosis

Widespread endothelial activation and activation of coagulation cascade and this results in widespread thrombosis in small vessels 

Net effect as you progress through this storm is a very sick patient, oedematous, blood volume being lost form vascular space into tissues and multiple failing organs with a myriad of complex metabolic derangements.

What does this patient have?
•{{c1::20}}% of patients with severe sepsis

Name other 2 types of causes and 2 examples from each for the patient?
•Clinical and radiological diagnosis: Bilateral infiltrates and arterial hypoxaemia without cardiac failure

After 1-2 weeks of repair, gives rise to
regeneration of normal structure, unless fibrous plugs form

Acute renal failure occurs in {{c1::20}}% of patients with sepsis and {{c1::50}}% of those with septic shock

Acute Kidney Injury is irreversible, T/F {{c1::False}}

Kidney histology, what are red arrows?

Brain in severe sepsis
•Pathology is due to the {{c1::cytokine}} effect and is manifested by:

-{{c1::Oedema}} (initially vasogenic then cytotoxic if cells are damaged)

-{{c1::Hypoxic ischaemic encephalopathy (HIE)}}
^{{c1::Hippocampus}} > cerebellar nuclei >   {{c1::watershed}} areas
^{{c1::Red}} neurons indicate irreversible injury

What is the sepsis 6?
How long should it be done?

•Subsequent bundle of care focusses on monitoring and supporting organ function

•Surgical removal of {{c1::septic foci}} and {{c1::necrotic}} tissue is essential;infarcted bowel, necrotising fascia, retained products

•Indirect therapies: aimed at modifying the {{c1::systemic inflammatory}} response; immunomodulatory therapies and clinical trials of alternative agents

Sepsis 6:
Take: blood cultures; bloods (FBC, lactate); urine output
Give: oxygen, fluids, antimicrobials

1st 6 hours

•Blood transfusions remain the #1 most common {{c1::allogeneic tissue}} transplant in medicine

-{{c1::Bacteria}} are the most common pathogens

-Whole blood is separated by {{c1::differential centrifugation}}

Name 3 blood components, 
{{c1::
•Red Blood Cells (RBC’s)
•Platelets
•Plasma
}}

Components of Plasma proteins:
 {{c1::Intravenous immune}} globulin (IVIg), {{c1::Coagulation}} Factors, 
{{c1::albumin}}, 
Anti-{{c1::D}}, 
Growth {{c1::Factors}}, 
{{c1::Colloid}} volume expanders

•{{c1::Apheresis}} : is a medical technology in which the blood of a person is passed through an apparatus that separates out {{c1::one particular constituent and returns the remainder to the circulation}}. It is thus an extracorporeal therapy

.Order the following in density: leukocytes, erthyrocytes, plasma

Which is whole blood, red blood cells, platelets?

•4° for up to 42 days, can be frozen
•Up to 5 days at 20-24°
•4° for up to 35 days
-coagulation factors will not be active after 3-5 days
- anemia, hypoxia
- Massive Blood Loss
-Usual dose 10 cc/kg 
-Usually transfuse over 2-4 hours 
-Thrombocytopenia, what is the threshold of it ?{{c1::<15,000}}
•Contain Leukocytes and cytokines
•1 unit/10 kg of body weight increases Plt count by {{c1::50,000}}

---------------------------------------
Whole blood: Donor and recipient must be ABO compatible, T/F? {{c1::False identical}}

Platelets: Donor and Recipient must be ABO identical, T/F? {{c1::True}}

whole blood
•4° for up to 35 days
- Massive Blood Loss
-coagulation factors will not be active after 3-5 days#

red blood cells
•4° for up to 42 days, can be frozen
- anemia, hypoxia
-Usual dose 10 cc/kg 
-Usually transfuse over 2-4 hours 

platelets
•Up to 5 days at 20-24°
-Thrombocytopenia <15,000
•Bleeding and Plt <50,000
•Invasive procedure and Plt <50,000
•Contain Leukocytes and cytokines
•1 unit/10 kg of body weight increases Plt count by 50,000

Plasma and FFP
Storage
•FFP--{{c1::12}} months at –{{c1::18}} degrees or colder

Indications
•{{c1::Coagulation Factor}} deficiency, {{c1::fibrinogen}} replacement, DIC, {{c1::liver}} disease, exchange transfusion, massive transfusion

Considerations
•Plasma should be recipient RBC ABO {{c1::compatible}}
•In children, should also be {{c1::Rh}} compatible
•Account for time to {{c1::thaw}}
•Usual dose is {{c1::20}} cc/kg to raise coagulation factors approx {{c1::20}}%

Cryoprecipitate
Precipitate formed/collected when FFP is thawed at {{c1::4}}°

Storage
•After collection, refrozen and stored up to {{c1::12}} months at -{{c1::18}}°

Indication
•{{c1::Fibrinogen (dysfibrinogenemia)}} deficiency 
•{{c1::vonWillebrands}} Disease
•Factor {{c1::VIII}} or {{c1::XIII}} deficiency
•DIC (not used alone)

Considerations
•Usual dose is 1 unit/{{c1::5-10}} kg of recipient body weight

ABO identical, T/F? {{c1:: False ABO compatible preferred (but not limiting)}}

What is the difference between FFP and cryoprecipitate?
FFP contains coagulation factors at the same concentration present in plasma. Cryoprecipitate is a highly concentrated source of fibrinogen

Granulocyte Transfusions
Why are they prepared at the time for immediate transfusion? {{c1::no storage available}}

Indications 
– severe {{c1::neutropenia}} assoc with infection that has failed antibiotic therapy
•Donor is given G-CSF {{c1::Granulocyte colony stimulating factor}} and steroids or Hetastarch

What is hetastarch used for?{{c1::treat hypovolemia}}

Complications
•Severe {{c1::allergic}} reactions
•Can {{c1::irradiate}} granulocytes for Graft versus host disease prevention

Name 3 transfusion complications + give 2 examples
{{c1::
•Acute Transfusion Reactions (ATR’s)
•Chronic Transfusion Reactions
•Transfusion related infections
}}

Acute Transfusion Reactions (ATR’s)
•Hemolytic Reactions (AHTR)
•Febrile Reactions (FNHTR)
•Allergic Reactions
•TRALI
•Coagulopathy with Massive transfusions
•Bacteremia

Chronic Transfusion Reactions
-Alloimmunization
-Graft verses Host Disease
-Iron overload
-Transfusion transmitted infection(this is what he has in the slides, I know it is its own complication)

Match these up:
1.Febrile Nonhemolytic Transfusion Reactions (FNHTR)
2.Allergic Nonhemolytic Transfusion Reactions
3.TRALI Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury
4.Massive Transfusions
5.Acute Hemolytic Transfusion Reactions (AHTR)
-------------------------------------------------------------
A. Occurs when incompatible RBC’s are transfused into a recipient who has pre-formed antibodies (usually ABO or Rh), Antibodies activate the complement system, Symptoms occur within minutes of starting the transfusion

B. Rise in patient temperature >1°C (associated with transfusion without other fever precipitating factors), Occurs with approx 1% of PRBC transfusions and approx 20% of Plt transfusions

C. May be due to plasma proteins or blood preservative/anticoagulant, Best characterized with IgA given to an IgA deficient patients with anti-IgA antibodies 

D. Clinical syndrome similar to ARDS, Occurs 1-6 hours after receiving plasma-containing blood products, Caused by WBC antibodies present in donor blood that result in pulmonary leukostasis

E. Coagulopathy may occur, Coagulopathy is caused by failure to replace plasma

AHTR Lab results. True or False?
•Hemoglobinemia {{c1::True}}
•Negative DAT {{c1::False positive DAT}}
•Hemoglobinuria {{c1::True}}
•Hypobilirubinemia {{c1::False Hyperbilirubinemia}}

What is missing?
{{c1::•Abnormal DIC panel }}

Monitoring in AHTR
Name 3 things that need to be monitored apart from vital/clinical status. {{c1::renal status, coagulation status, signs of hemolysis }}

Transfusion Associated GVHD
•Etiology—Results from engraftment of donor {{c1::lymphocytes}} of an immunoc{{c1::ompetent}} donor into an immunoc{{c1::ompromised}} host
-Usually fatal, T/F? {{c1::True, no treatment}}
Name 2 types of infections

Alloimmunization
What blood components can it occur with?

Transfusion Associated GVHD
•Hepatitis C
•Hepatitis B
•HIV
•CMV (can be diminished by leukoreduction, which is indicated for immunocompromised patients)

Alloimmunization
-Can occur with erythrocytes or platelets
Erythrocytes
•Antigen disparity of minor antigens (Kell, Duffy, Kidd)
•Minor antigens D, K, E seen in Sickle patients

Platelets
•Usually due to HLA antigens
•May reduce alloimmunization by leukoreduction (since WBC’s present the HLA antigens)

{{c1::Haemostasis}}: the arresting of bleeding
depends on several components,
which doesn't belong?
•Vascular system
•Red and White Blood Cells
•Platelets (thrombocytes)
•Blood coagulation factors
•Fibrinolysis and ultimate tissue repair

•Vascular system
•Platelets (thrombocytes)
•Blood coagulation factors
•Fibrinolysis and ultimate tissue repair

{{c1::Thrombosis}}: An inappropriate activation of normal haemostatic processes, such as formation of a thrombus in uninjured vasculature or thrombotic occlusion of a vessel after relatively minor injury.

{{c1::Thrombus}}: solid mass formed within the vascular system (blood vessel or cardiac chamber) in life from the constituents of flowing blood.

Thrombi have laminations called {{c1::lines of Zahn}}.bolus: A detached solid, liquid or gaseous 

{{c1::Embolus}}: A dtached solid, liquigaseous mass that is carried by the blood to a site distnt from its point of origin.
-Lines of Zahn are produced by alternating pale layers of platelets admixed with fibrin and darker layers containing more red cells.
Virchow’s triad: 3 primary influences predisposing to thrombus, name them

1.Endothelial injury
2.Alteration of blood flow (stasis, turbulence)
3. Blood hypercoagulability
Name 2 causes of alteration in blood flow

-Stasis: major factor in development of venous thrombi.
§Inactivity
§Mitral valve stenosis → left atrial dilatation
-Turbulence: causes endothelial injury and also forms countercurrents and local pockets of stasis.
§Aneurysms

Venous thrombi
DVT – deep venous thrombosis

-Usually occur in sites of {{c1::stasis}}.

-Extend in the direction of blood flow (propagation). T/F?

-Deep venous thrombi rarely embolise but may lead to varicose ulcers. T/F?

- Name 2 risk factors

-Usually occur in sites of stasis.

True
-Extend in the direction of blood flow (propagation).

False
-Superficial venous thrombi rarely embolise but may lead to varicose ulcers.

-Risk factors: immobilisation (e.g. longhaul travel),  post-surgery, OCP, smoking, advanced age, obesity, cancer, pregnancy, inherited thrombophilia

Arterial thrombi
-Most common sites: (3) {{c1::coronary , cerebral, femoral arteries.}}

-Usually occlude the artery causing {{c1::ischaemia}}

-Rarely embolise. T/F

Cardiac thrombi (mural thrombi)
-Most commonly occur with:
-ventricular fibrillation
-before an MI. T/F?

-May {{c1::embolise}} to brain, peripheral arteries, spleen.

Rarely embolise.  = true

False
¡Most commonly occur with:
§atrial fibrillation
§after an MI

Pulmonary thromboembolus (PE)

->95% of cases: PEs originate from {{c1::above-knee}} DVTs

-60-80% are clinically {{c1::silent}}

-{{c1::Saddle embolus}}: a large PE which impacts across the bifurcation of the pulmonary arteries → sudden death due to acute right heart failure

Saddle embolus

¡Multiple small emboli: can embolise off a single large mass → pulmonary haemorrhage or pulmonary infarction
¡Multiple emboli over time → pulmonary hypertension and chronic right heart failure

Treatment of DVT/PE
-LMW (Low-molecular-weight) {{c1::heparin}} and oral {{c1::anticoagulant}}

-{{c1::Thrombolytic therapy}} in PE with haemodynamic instability

-{{c1::IVC filter}} indicated if contraindication to/failure of anticoagulation

Systemic thromboembolus
-80% arise from {{c1::intracardiac mural}} thrombi

¡Majority occur as a result of :
§LV infarction
§Atrial dilation 
§Atrial fibrillation 
§Mitral fibrillation 
Which is the odd one out?

What is a Paradoxical embolism ?

Mitral fibrillation isn't one

§LV infarction
§Atrial dilation 
§Atrial fibrillation 

Paradoxical embolism occurs when pulmonary artery and right heart pressures rise with continued embolization, promoting the passage of the material through a patent foramen ovale

Fat/bone marrow embolus
-Fat globules enter the bloodstream through {{c1::tissue (usually bone marrow or adipose tissue)}} that has been disrupted by trauma

-Occurs after fractures of short bones, T/F?

-Presents {{c1::1-3 days}} after injury. (time interval)

- What is the Classic triad?

False
-Occurs after fractures of long bones, e.g. femur.

¡Classic triad – hypoxemia, neurologic abnormalities, petechial rash

-Management is supportive. Mortality 5 - 15%.

Air embolus

-Two conditions necessary:
1.{{c1::direct communication between a source of air and the vasculature}}
2.{{c1::pressure gradient favouring the passage of air into the circulation rather than bleeding}}

-Need >{{c1::100}}ml to have a clinical effect. 

-{{c1::300 to 500}} mL of gas introduced at a rate of {{c1::100}} mL/sec is a fatal dose for humans 

The major reason for this is that the surgical incision is usually superior/inferior to the heart at a distance that is greater than the central venous pressure. This sets up a condition of positive/negative venous pressure relative to the atmosphere, which favours the passage of air into the circulation, especially when the patient is in a sitting/standing position.

The major reason for this is that the surgical incision is usually superior to the heart at a distance that is greater than the central venous pressure. This sets up a condition of negative venous pressure relative to the atmosphere, which favours the passage of air into the circulation, especially when the patient is in a sitting position.

Amniotic fluid embolism
What causes it?

-Precipitates {{c1::cardiogenic}} shock, {{c1::respiratory}} failure, and an {{c1::inflammatory}} response.

-Amniotic fluid enters the maternal
circulation through the endocervical veins, the placental insertion site, or a
site of uterine trauma

{{c1::Ischaemia}}:restriction in blood supply (from either reduced arterial flow or reduced venous drainage) which causes oxygen deprivation and results in tissue damage.

-However, sometimes, cells proceed to die after blood flow resumes: {{c1::reperfusion injury}}
Why (2)?

1.Re-oxygenation increases generation of oxygen free radicals causing new damage
2.Production of cytokines recruits circulating neutrophils to reperfused tissue resulting in inflammation.

{{c1::Infarction}}: An area of ischaemic necrosis caused by occlusion of either the arterial supply or the venous drainage in a particular tissue. 

Vast majority of infarcts due to thrombotic /embolic events, almost all due to {{c1::arterial}} occlusion

•{{c1::Venous thrombosis}} more often induces venous obstruction and congestion rather than infarction.
What are the exceptions?

Exception: organs with a single venous outflow channel,
e.g. testis or ovary

Which is white vs. red infarct?
A With venous occlusions (testis, ovary).

B In loose tissues such as lung which allow blood to collect in the infarcted zone.

C Occur with arterial occlusions or in solid organs (e.g. heart, spleen, kidney) where the solidity of the tissue limits the amount of haemorrhage that can seep into the area of ischaemic necrosis from adjoining capillary beds.

D In tissues with dual circulations (e.g. lung, liver) allowing flow of blood from the unobstructed vessel into the necrotic zone (but not enough perfusion to restore the ischaemic tissues).

Infarction - morphology
-Gross: All infarcts tend to be {{c1::wedge-shaped}}, with the {{c1::occluded vessel}} at the apex and {{c1::the periphery of the organ}} forming the base.

-Microscopy: The dominant histologic characteristic of infarction is ischaemic {{c1::coagulative necrosis}}.
-Takes a while for changes to be demonstrable {{c1::histologically}}.

Septic infarcts
-occur when embolisation occurs by {{c1::fragmentation of a bacterial vegetation from a heart valve}} or {{c1::when microbes seed an area of necrotic tissue.}}

-The infarct gets converted into an {{c1::abscess}}.

α1 Adrenoreceptor

G-Protein Coupled Receptors
Transmembrane receptors with {{c1::4}} EC domains and {{c1::3}} IC domains.

Coupled to three G-protein subunits intracellularly - α, β, γ.
αs stimulates AC to produce of {{c1::cAMP}}
αi inhibits {{c1::cAMP}} production 
αq stimulates {{c1::PLCβ}} production

Gαs causes smooth muscle {{c1::relaxation}} but increases cardiac muscle {{c1::contractility}}.
Gαi/o facilitates smooth muscle {{c1::contractility}}.
Gαq promotes {{c1::Ca2+}} release and smooth muscle contractility

HOW ARE SNS MODULATORS USED TO AFFECT BLOOD PRESSURE?
-{{c1::Alpha-2}} agonists are used to stimulate presynaptic inhibition of NA release
-{{c1::Beta-1}} antagonists are used for: effect on cardiac contractility effect at juxtaglomerular apparatus to inhibit renin
-{{c1::Alpha-1}} antagonists are used for their direct effect on vascular smooth muscle

Broad-ranging effects on short and longterm BP control

Predominantly intracellular calcium from {{c1::SR}} is most important.
Extracellular calcium {{c1::influx}} through the voltage dependent {{c1::L-type}}
• [Ca2+]i is 10,000 times {{c1::lower}} than [Ca2+]e

What type of drugs are Inhibitors of α1AR (adrenoceptors)?
{{c1::The -azocins; Prazoscin Doxazoscin}}


Block the activation of {{c1::PLC}} by α1AR.
 ->↓ Release of intracellular calcium from SR 
Also increase NE in cleft for {{c1::α2AR}} 
Increased {{c1::pre}}-synaptic modulation
INHIBIT {{c1::CALMODULIN}} MEDIATED ACTIVATION OF MLCK


What effects do these have?
{{c1::PROMOTE SMOOTH MUSCLE RELAXATION AND INHIBIT CONTRACTILITY}}

What type of drugs are Dihydropyridine L-Type Calcium Channel Antagonists?
{{c1::-dipine; Nifedipine Amlodipine Lercanidipine}}

Selective effect on {{c1::vascular}} smooth muscle
Inhibits {{c1::calcium}} dependent calmodulin

PHARMACOKINETICS 
1. Orally active 
2. {{c1::High}} first-pass metabolism 
3. {{c1::Low}} bioavailability ~20%
4. {{c1::High}} plasma protein binding 
5. {{c1::Extensive}} hepatic metabolism 
6. {{c1::Long}} T1/2

Why aren't nitrates usually used (2)?
{{c1::Short-lived agents taken S/L, S/C, IV or Orally 
Associated with tolerance and headache}}

COMMONLY USED IN THE MANAGEMENT OF {{c1::ANGINA}} and why (2)?
{{c1::
1. Reduce the afterload of the heart by reducing peripheral resistance 
2. Useful in the management of acute hypertension}}

Stimulate the production of {{c1::cGMP}} which activates {{c1::PKG}} and inhibits [Ca2+]i

β- Blockers
Work as antihypertensive agents by inhibiting {{c1::Renin}} release

{{c1::Juxtaglomerular}} cells - SNS supply - β{{c1::1}}AR specific.

Ironically their direct SM effect to block β{{c1::2}}AR removes vasodilator stimulus and can also stimulate {{c1::bronchconstriction}}.

THERAPEUTIC EFFECTS
1. {{c1::⬇︎}} Heart rate - no effect on blood pressure 
2. Reduction in {{c1::angiotensin II}} - Removal of vasoconstriction  
3. Inhibition of {{c1::aldosterone}} production - Mild diuretic effect

What type of hypotension would a person have?
{{c1::Postural hypotension}}

Predominant area of action within CNS {{c1::vasomotor}} centres.
